ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed skills in German speaking, vocabulary, and grammar. We also learned aspects of German speaking culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Intone but very well taught, high workload
This class could be improved by replacing the asynchronous day with a low-stakes conversation class, possibly with a tutor to practice speaking skills.

Strengths: course was overall interesting, reasonable, and informative. Weaknesses: the class seemed to evaluate your ability to speak German before coming into the class more than what you actually learned during class. That mean that students who had previously studied a lot of German we're at a significant advantage, and it felt like it was harder for students who had only started learning German at Yale to keep up.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you want to learn German and already have a semester of college/year of high school's worth of knowledge, then take this class. As far as languages at Yale go, it's pretty good. The class isn't as challenging as some languages, but is also not a joke like some others. You'll work a bit, but you'll learn too and the grading is fair.
